next_sentence: I have, in short, followed different     plans, but in every case have taken all the precautions which I could     think of, so that the two lots should be equally favoured.

question: With hermaphrodite plants we incessantly meet with [MASK] and perfect contrivances for this same end.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Therefore we should bear in mind that with all hermaphrodite animals, as far as I can learn, their structure permits and frequently necessitates a cross with a distinct individual.
next_sentence: It is no exaggeration to assert that, if the use of the talons and tusks of a carnivorous animal, or the use of the viscid threads of a spider's web, or of the plumes and hooks on a seed may be safely inferred from their structure, we may with equal safety infer that many flowers are constructed for the express purpose of ensuring a cross with a distinct plant.

question: Methodical selection is that which guides a man who systematically endeavours to [MASK] a breed according to some predetermined standard.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: The principle of selection may be conveniently divided into three kinds.
next_sentence: Unconscious selection is that which follows from men naturally preserving the most valued and destroying the less valued individuals, without any thought of altering the breed; and undoubtedly this process slowly works great changes.

question: Colour is generally esteemed by the systematic naturalist as unimportant: let us, therefore, see how far it indirectly affects our domestic [MASK], and how far it would affect them if they were left exposed to the full force of natural selection.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: It is obvious that a host of artificial races could never survive in a state of nature;--such as Italian greyhounds,--hairless and almost toothless Turkish dogs,--fantail pigeons, which cannot fly well against a strong wind,--barbs with their vision impeded by their eye-wattle,--Polish fowls with their vision impeded by their great topknots,--hornless bulls and rams which consequently cannot cope with other males, and thus have a poor chance of leaving offspring,--seedless plants, and many other such cases.
next_sentence: In a future chapter I shall have to show that constitutional peculiarities of the strangest kind, entailing liability to the action of certain poisons, are correlated with the colour of the skin.

question: These changes are well shown by placing on the same stigma, at the same time, the plant's own pollen and that from a distinct plant of the same species, or of another species, or even of another and widely remote [MASK].
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: The     discolouration and decay are not caused by parasitic cryptogams, which     were observed by Fritz Mueller in only a single instance.
next_sentence: Thus, on the stigma of Oncidium flexuosum, the plant's own pollen and     that from a distinct plant were placed side by side, and in five days'     time the latter was perfectly fresh, whilst the plant's own pollen was     brown.

question: Fixedness of character, or the strength of inheritance, has often been judged of by the preponderance of certain characters in the crossed offspring between distinct races; but prepotency of transmission here comes into play, and this, as we shall immediately see, is a very different consideration from the [MASK] or weakness of inheritance.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: But we must believe structures, which have already varied, would be more liable to go on varying, rather than structures which during an immense lapse of time have remained unaltered; and this variation is probably the result of certain relations between the conditions of life and the organisation, quite independently of the greater or less antiquity of each particular character.
next_sentence: It has often been observed[136] that breeds of animals inhabiting wild and mountainous countries cannot be permanently modified by our improved breeds; and as these latter are of modern origin, it has been thought that the greater antiquity of the wilder breeds has been the cause of their resistance to improvement by crossing; but it is more probably due to their structure and constitution being better adapted to the surrounding conditions.

question: It would appear that the pollen or ovules, or both, of the individual plants which are in this abnormal state, have been affected in some strange manner by the conditions to which they themselves or their parents have been exposed; but whilst thus rendered self-sterile, they have retained the [MASK] common to most species of partially fertilizing and being partially fertilized by allied forms.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: For in these latter the two sexual elements of the same individual plant are capable of freely acting on each other; but are so constituted that they are more or less impotent when brought into union with the sexual elements of a distinct species, and produce more or less sterile hybrids.
next_sentence: However this may be, the subject, to a certain extent, is related to our general conclusion that good is derived from the act of crossing.

question: These can then be properly united in a [MASK] manner.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: It is possible to raise from dimorphic species, both long-styled and short-styled illegitimate plants, and from trimorphic plants all three illegitimate forms.
next_sentence: When this is done, there is no apparent reason why they should not yield as many seeds as did their parents when legitimately fertilised.

question: This variegation of the plumage, however, disappears with the first moult; but among the next [MASK] families there are always a few pied ones . ''
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: 1837, "have several of their brood     particoloured, black and white.
next_sentence: These changes of plumage,     which appear and are inherited at various corresponding periods of life     in the pigeon, canary-bird, and rook, are remarkable, because the     parent-species undergo no such change.

question: There is no reason to suppose that organs which have been rendered monstrous have [MASK] been acted on during their development; the cause may have acted on the organisation at a much earlier stage.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: But the nature of the food     given to a caterpillar sometimes affects the colours of the moth,     without the caterpillar itself being affected; therefore it seems     possible that other characters in the mature insect might be indirectly     modified through the larvae.
next_sentence: It is even probable that either the male or female     sexual elements, or both, before their union, may be affected in such a     manner as to lead to modifications in organs developed at a late period     of life; in nearly the same manner as a child may inherit from his     father a disease which does not appear until old age.

question: We see the same connexion in those rare cases in which the hair has been renewed in old age, for this has``usually been accompanied by a renewal of the [MASK]. ''
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: With man several striking cases have been recorded[819] of inherited baldness with {327} inherited deficiency, either complete or partial, of the teeth.
next_sentence: I have remarked in a former part of this volume that the great reduction in the size of the tusks in domestic boars probably stands in close relation with their diminished bristles, due to a certain amount of protection; and that the reappearance of the tusks in boars, which have become feral and are fully exposed to the weather, probably depends on the reappearance of the bristles.

question: In this case, and in many others, we can only [MASK] that changed habits of life apparently have favoured a tendency, inherent or latent in the species, to return to the primitive state.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: But the reappearance of coloured longitudinal stripes on young feral pigs cannot be attributed to the direct action of external conditions.
next_sentence: It will be shown in a future chapter that the position of flowers on the summit of the axis, and the position of seeds within the capsule, sometimes determine a tendency towards reversion; and this apparently depends on the amount of sap or nutriment which the flower-buds and seeds receive.

question: In some of these [MASK] the flower-heads were also proliferous.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Dr. Masters has briefly described another leguminous     plant,[862] namely, a species of clover, in which the uppermost and     central flowers were regular or had lost their papilionaceous     structure.
next_sentence: Lastly, Linaria produces two kinds of peloric flowers, one having     simple petals, and the other having them all spurred.

question: Hence ovules and pollen-grains ,--the fertilised seed or egg, as well as buds ,--include and consist of a [MASK] of germs thrown off from each separate atom of the organism.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Under this point of view I venture to advance the hypothesis of Pangenesis, which {358} implies that the whole organisation, in the sense of every separate atom or unit, reproduces itself.
next_sentence: In the First Part I will enumerate as briefly as I can the groups of facts which seem to demand connection; but certain subjects, not hitherto discussed, must be treated at disproportionate length.

question: Unless the crossed offspring were slaughtered by man without the least [MASK], some degree of unmethodical selection would likewise come into action.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Should both varieties exist in nearly equal numbers, it is probable that a considerable period would elapse before the acquirement of a uniform character; and the character ultimately acquired would largely depend on prepotency of transmission, and on the conditions of life; for the nature of these conditions would generally favour one variety more than another, so that a kind of natural selection would come into play.
next_sentence: From these several considerations we may infer, that when two or more closely allied species first came into the possession of the same tribe, their crossing will not have influenced, in so great a degree as has often been supposed, the character of the offspring in future times; although in some cases it probably has had a considerable effect.

question: An opposite conclusion, however, [MASK] to me the more probable.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: When, on the     other hand, he crossed cultivated plants, he admits that new characters     occasionally appeared, but he is strongly inclined to attribute their     appearance to ordinary variability, not in any way to the cross.
next_sentence: According to Koelreuter, hybrids in the genus Mirabilis vary almost     infinitely, and he describes new and singular characters in the form of     the seeds, in the colour of the anthers, in the cotyledons being of     immense size, in new and highly peculiar odours, in the flowers     expanding early in the season, and in their closing at night.

question: Firstly, a tendency in every character, new and old, to be transmitted by seminal and bud generation, though often [MASK] by various known and unknown causes.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Finally, though much remains obscure with respect to Inheritance, we may look at the following laws as fairly well established.
next_sentence: Secondly, reversion or atavism, which depends on transmission and development being distinct powers: it acts in various degrees and manners through both seminal and bud generation.

question: It is remarkable that many plants under these circumstances are so much affected that the [MASK] and the nature of their chemical ingredients are modified, yet their fertility is unimpaired.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Plants which have been long cultivated can generally endure with     undiminished fertility various and great changes; but not in most cases     so great a change of climate as domesticated animals.
next_sentence: Thus, as Dr. Falconer     informs me, there is a great difference in the character of the fibre     in hemp, in the quantity of oil in the seed of the Linum, in the     proportion of narcotin to morphine in the poppy, in gluten to starch in     wheat, when these plants are cultivated on the plains and on the     mountains of India; nevertheless, they all remain fully fertile.

question: Our bulldogs [MASK] from those which were formerly used for baiting bulls.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: So it has been with dogs; our present fox-hounds differ from the old English hound; our greyhounds have become lighter; the wolf-dog, which belonged to the greyhound class, has become extinct; the Scotch deer-hound has been modified, and is now rare.
next_sentence: Our pointers and Newfoundlands do not {212} closely resemble any native dog now found in the countries whence they were brought, These changes have been effected partly by crosses; but in every case the result has been governed by the strictest selection.

question: We have still better [MASK] of this in closely parallel varieties being frequently produced from distinct races, or even distinct species, and in the frequent recurrence of the same monstrosity in the same species.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: We have evidence of this in the appearance of nearly similar modifications under different conditions, and of different modifications under apparently nearly the same conditions.
next_sentence: We have also seen that the degree to which domesticated birds have varied, does not stand in any close relation with the amount of change to which they have been subjected.

question: As far as variability depends on the imperfect action of the reproductive organs under changed conditions, we can at once see why seedlings should be [MASK] more variable than plants propagated by buds.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Another difficulty may be here noticed; we have seen that {396} there is an important difference in the frequency, though not in the nature, of the variations in plants propagated by sexual and asexual generation.
next_sentence: We know that extremely slight causes,--for instance, whether a tree has been grafted or grows on its own stock, the position of the seeds within the capsule, and of the flowers on the spike,--sometimes suffice to determine the variation of a plant, when raised from seed.

question: Excess of nutriment is perhaps the most efficient single [MASK] cause.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Changes of any kind in the conditions of life, even extremely slight changes, often suffice to cause variability.
next_sentence: Animals and plants continue to be variable for an immense period after their first domestication; but the conditions to which they are exposed never long remain quite constant.

question: With domesticated productions organs sometimes become rudimentary through abortion; but we have no reason to [MASK] that this has ever followed from mere disuse.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Disuse has a contrary effect.
next_sentence: With natural species, on the contrary, many organs appear to have been rendered rudimentary through disuse, aided by the principle of the economy of growth, and by the hypothetical principle discussed in the last chapter, namely, the final destruction of the germs or gemmules of such useless parts.

question: Owing to inheritance being limited by sex, we can see how secondary sexual characters may first have arisen under [MASK]; their preservation and accumulation being dependent on their service to either sex.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Occasionally these two powers seem to be antagonistic, or incapable of combination in the same individual; for several cases have been recorded in which the son has not directly inherited a character from his father, or directly transmitted it to his son, but has received it by transmission through his non-affected mother, and transmitted it through his non-affected daughter.
next_sentence: At whatever period of life a new character first appears, it generally remains latent in the offspring until a corresponding age is attained, and then it is developed.

question: The most striking instances of luxuriant growth have been [MASK] with hybrids which were not sterile in any extreme degree.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: This view seems at first sight extremely     probable, and has been accepted by various authors;[299] but     Gaertner[300] has well remarked that there is much difficulty in fully     admitting it; for with many hybrids there is no parallelism between the     degree of their sterility and their increased size and vigour.
next_sentence: In the genus Mirabilis,     certain hybrids are unusually fertile, and their extraordinary     luxuriance of growth, together with their enormous roots,[301] have     been transmitted to their progeny.

question: There is a manifest relation between a crest of feathers on the head and a marvellous amount of change in the skull of various fowls; and in a lesser degree, between the greatly elongated, lopping ears of [MASK] and the structure of their skulls.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: When long feathers grow from the outside of the legs and toes of pigeons, the two outer toes are connected by membrane; for the whole leg tends to assume the structure of the wing.
next_sentence: With plants, the leaves, various parts of the flower, and the fruit, often vary together in a correlated manner.

question: The assumed elective affinity of each gemmule for that particular cell which precedes it in the order of development is supported by many [MASK].
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: But this non-diffusion of the gemmules from bud to bud may be only apparent, depending, as we shall hereafter see, on the nature of the first-formed cells in the buds.
next_sentence: In all ordinary cases of sexual reproduction the male and female elements have a mutual affinity for each other: thus, it is believed that about ten thousand species of Compositae exist, and there can be no doubt that if the pollen of all these species could be, simultaneously or successively, placed on the stigma of any one species, this one would elect with unerring certainty its own pollen.

question: When any one part of the body or quality is not attended to, it remains either unchanged or varies in a fluctuating [MASK], whilst at the same time other parts and other qualities may become permanently and greatly modified.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Whenever and {248} wherever selection is not practised, distinct races are not formed.
next_sentence: But from the tendency to reversion and to continued variability, those parts or organs which are now undergoing rapid improvement through selection, are likewise found to vary much.

question: So it is in every case, and the large price paid for first-rate animals [MASK] the difficulty of breeding them up to the highest standard of excellence.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Thus with short-faced tumbler-pigeons, the shortness of the beak, shape of head and plumage,--with carriers, the length of the beak and wattle,--with fantails, the tail and carriage,--with Spanish fowls, the white face and comb,--with long-eared rabbits, the length of ear, are all points which are eminently variable.
next_sentence: This subject has been discussed by fanciers,[586] and the greater prizes given for highly improved breeds, in comparison with those given for old breeds which are not now undergoing rapid improvement, has been fully justified.

question: Polish fowls have a large tuft of feathers on their heads; and their skulls are perforated by numerous holes, so that a pin can be driven into the brain without touching any [MASK].
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: From the analogical case of the dog, hereafter to be given, it is probable that the shortening of the nasal and adjoining bones is the proximate cause of the other modifications in the skull, including the upward curvature of the lower jaw, though we cannot follow out the steps by which these changes have been effected.
next_sentence: That this deficiency of bone is in some way connected with the tuft of feathers is clear from tufted ducks and geese likewise having {333} perforated skulls.

question: On the contrary, we [MASK] see that structures which are rudimentary in the parent-species become partially redeveloped in their domesticated progeny.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: The cause of this difference probably is that with domestic animals not only sufficient time has not been granted for so profound a change, but that, from not being exposed to a severe struggle for life, the principle of the economy of organisation does not come into action.
next_sentence: When rudiments are formed or left under domestication, they are the result of a sudden arrest of development, and not of long-continued disuse with the absorption of all superfluous parts; nevertheless they are of interest, as showing that rudiments are the relics of organs once perfectly developed.

question: With respect to the mammae in [MASK], see tom.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)

question: And the principle of inheritance as limited by sex shows how such characters might have been [MASK] acquired and subsequently modified.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: With our domesticated animals, also, these same secondary characters are often found to differ greatly from the state in which they exist in the parent-species.
next_sentence: Dr. P. Lucas, who has collected many facts on this subject, shows[160]     that when a peculiarity, in no manner connected with the reproductive     organs, appears in either parent, it is often transmitted exclusively     to the offspring of the same sex, or to a much greater number of them     than of the opposite sex.

question: On the whole it is probable that any cause affecting the organs of reproduction would likewise [MASK] their product ,--that is, the offspring thus generated.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: From these considerations it would seem that     changes in the conditions of life lead either to sterility or to     variability, or to both; and not that sterility induces variability.
next_sentence: {269}      The period of life at which the causes that induce variability act, is     another obscure subject, which has been discussed by various     authors.

question: Lastly, many hybrids are profuse and persistent flowerers, whilst other and more sterile hybrids produce few flowers, and are weak, miserable dwarfs; exactly similar cases occur with the illegitimate offspring of various dimorphic and trimorphic [MASK].
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: With hybrids raised from the same seed-capsule the degree of sterility is innately variable, so it is in a marked manner with illegitimate plants.
next_sentence: Altogether there is the closest identity in character and behaviour between illegitimate plants and hybrids.

question: But the belief that double monsters originate from the division of one germ, does not necessarily [MASK] the question of subsequent fusion, or render less true the law of the affinity of homologous parts.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Double monsters were formerly thought to be formed by the union of two originally distinct embryos developed upon distinct vitelli; but now it is admitted that "their production is due to the spontaneous divarication of the embryonic mass into two halves;"[845] this, however, is effected by different methods.
next_sentence: The cautious and sagacious J. Mueller,[846] when speaking of Janus-like monsters, says, that "without the supposition that some kind of affinity or attraction is exerted between corresponding parts, unions of this kind are inexplicable."

question: From the facts to be given, it will also be seen that natural selection would powerfully affect many of our domestic productions if left [MASK].
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Although nature is difficult to resist, yet man often strives against her power, and sometimes, as we shall see, with {226} success.
next_sentence: This is a point of much interest, for we thus learn that differences apparently of very slight importance would certainly determine the survival of a form when forced to struggle for its own existence.

question: This subject has been here noticed, because we may infer that, when any part or organ is either greatly increased in size or wholly suppressed through variation and continued selection, the co-ordinating power of the organisation will continually [MASK] to bring all the parts again into harmony with each other.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: [726] Yet this power is not     more wonderful than the growth and development of every single     creature, more especially of those which are propagated by fissiparous     generation.
next_sentence: On the Effects of the Increased Use and Disuse of Organs.  It is notorious, and we shall immediately adduce proofs, that increased use or action strengthens muscles, glands, sense-organs, &c.; and that disuse, on the other hand, weakens them.

question: With the exception of fertility, domestic varieties resemble species when crossed in transmitting their characters in the same unequal manner to their offspring, in being subject to the prepotency of one form over the other, and in their [MASK] to reversion.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: It is a nearly analogous fact, that most domestic races may be suddenly transported from one climate to another, or be placed under widely different conditions, and yet retain their fertility unimpaired; whilst a multitude of species subjected to lesser changes are rendered incapable of breeding.
next_sentence: By repeated crosses a variety or a species may be made completely to absorb another.

question: We need not, however, doubt that under nature new races and new species would become adapted to widely different climates, by spontaneous variation, [MASK] by habit, and regulated by natural selection.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: As no single instance has been recorded, either with animals or plants, of hardier individuals {315} having been long and steadily selected, though such selection is admitted to be indispensable for the improvement of any other character, it is not surprising that man has done little in the acclimatisation of domesticated animals and cultivated plants.
next_sentence: Arrests of Development: Rudimentary and Aborted Organs.      These subjects are here introduced because there is reason to believe     that rudimentary organs are in many cases the result of disuse.

question: These [MASK] in ordinary cases are wholly formed by the mother-plant.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Thus, when Gallesio fertilised an orange-flower with pollen from the lemon, the fruit bore stripes of perfectly characterised lemon-peel: with peas, several observers have seen the colour of the seed-coats and even of the pod directly affected by the pollen of a distinct variety; so it has been with the fruit of the apple, which consists of the modified calyx and upper part of the flower-stalk.
next_sentence: We here see the male element affecting and hybridising not that part which it is properly adapted to affect, namely the ovule, but the partially developed tissues of a distinct individual.

question: Now, if the pollen of a variety, when deposited on the stigma of the same variety, should become by spontaneous variation in ever so slight a degree prepotent over the pollen of other varieties, this would certainly be an advantage to the [MASK]; for its own pollen would thus obliterate the effects of the pollen of other varieties, and prevent deterioration of character.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: With many kinds, insects constantly carry pollen from neighbouring plants to the stigmas of each flower; and with some species this is effected by the wind.
next_sentence: And the more prepotent the variety's own pollen could be rendered through natural selection, the greater the advantage would be.

question: If, on the other hand, pollen which included the elements of one species happened to unite with ovules including the [MASK] of the other species, the intermediate or hybrid state would still be retained, and there would be no reversion.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: For this would be the natural result of the union of pollen and ovules, in both of which the elements of the same species had been segregated by self-affinity.
next_sentence: But it would, as I suspect, be more correct to say that the elements of both parent-species exist in every hybrid in a double state, namely, blended together and completely separate.

question: But we must be careful not to confound these cases of reversion to characters gained from a cross, with those given under the first class, in which characters originally common to both [MASK], but lost at some former period, reappear; for such characters may recur after an almost indefinite number of generations.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: It depends on the difference in the strength or prepotency of transmission in the two parent-forms, on their actual amount of difference, and on the nature of the conditions of life to which the crossed offspring are exposed.
next_sentence: {36}  The law of reversion is equally powerful with hybrids, when they are sufficiently fertile to breed together, or when they are repeatedly crossed with either pure parent-form, as with mongrels.

question: Cases of an opposite nature likewise occur, namely, plants with the female [MASK] struck with sterility, whilst the male organs remain perfect.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: There is perhaps an     additional cause, namely, self-fertilisation; for many plants of     Dianthus and Lobelia, which had been raised from self-fertilised seeds,     had their anthers in this state; but these instances are not     conclusive, as both genera are liable from other causes to this     affection.
next_sentence: Dianthus Japonicus, a Passiflora, and Nicotiana, have been     described by Gaertner[407] as being in this unusual condition.

question: The calyx sometimes assumes, either wholly or by [MASK], the colour and texture of the corolla.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: I have seen a leaflet low down in the compound leaf of Vicia sativa converted into a tendril, and a tendril possesses many peculiar properties, such as spontaneous movement and irritability.
next_sentence: Stamens are so frequently converted, more or less completely, into petals, that such cases are passed over as not deserving notice; but as petals have special functions to perform, namely, to protect the included organs, to attract insects, and in not a few cases to guide their entrance by well-adapted contrivances, we can hardly account for the conversion of stamens into petals merely by unnatural or superfluous nourishment.

question: New characters are [MASK] to become attached exclusively to that sex in which they first appeared, or they may be developed in a much higher degree in the one than the other sex; or again, after having become attached to one sex, they may be partially transferred to the opposite sex.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: These facts, simple as they appear, throw light on the characters which distinguish the larval and adult states of natural species, and on the whole great subject of embryology.
next_sentence: These facts, and more especially the circumstance that new characters seem to be particularly liable, from some unknown cause, to become attached to the male sex, have an important bearing on the acquirement by animals in a state of nature of secondary sexual characters.

question: Fifthly, inheritance at corresponding periods of life, with some tendency to the earlier [MASK] of the inherited character.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Fourthly, transmission, limited by sex, generally to the same sex in which the inherited character first appeared.
next_sentence: In these laws of Inheritance, as displayed under domestication, we see an ample provision for the production, through variability and natural selection, of new specific forms.

question: We can seldom tell what makes one race or species prepotent over another; but it sometimes depends on the same character being present and visible in one parent, and latent or potentially [MASK] in the other.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: It plays an important part in determining the rate at which one race can be modified or wholly absorbed by repeated crosses with another.
next_sentence: Characters may first appear in either sex, but oftener in the male than in the female, and afterwards be transmitted to the offspring of the same sex.

question: In accordance with what we know of the process of selection, the [MASK] of our many races has been slow and gradual.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Almost all our domesticated animals have given rise to numerous and distinct races, excepting those which cannot be easily subjected to selection--such as cats, the cochineal insect, and the hive-bee,--and excepting those animals which are not much valued.
next_sentence: The man who first observed and preserved a pigeon with its oesophagus a little enlarged, its beak a little longer, or its tail a little more expanded than usual, never dreamed that he had made the first step in the creation of the pouter, carrier, and fantail-pigeon.

question: Undoubtedly the principle has been systematically acknowledged and followed to a [MASK] greater extent within the last hundred years than at any former period, and a corresponding result has been gained; but it would be a great error to suppose, as we shall immediately see, that its importance was not recognised and acted on during the most ancient times, and by semi-civilised people.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: A distinguished naturalist considers it as absurd to suppose that semi-civilised people should have practised selection of any kind.
next_sentence: I should premise that many facts now to be given only show that care was taken in breeding; but when this is the case, selection is almost sure to be practised to a certain extent.

question: Some writers have doubted whether those complex mental [MASK], on which genius and talent depend, are inherited, even when both parents are thus endowed.

title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: I never heard of any one excepting this one man and his little daughter who had this strange habit; and certainly imitation was in this instance out of the question.
next_sentence: But he who will read Mr. Galton's able paper[11] on hereditary talent will have his doubts allayed.

question: It plays an important part in determining the rate at which one race can be modified or wholly absorbed by repeated [MASK] with another.

title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Prepotentcy of transmission may be equal in the two sexes of the same species, but often runs more strongly in one sex.
next_sentence: We can seldom tell what makes one race or species prepotent over another; but it sometimes depends on the same character being present and visible in one parent, and latent or potentially present in the other.

question: We shall appreciate this difficulty if we [MASK] to mind, what complex yet symmetrical growths the cells of plants yield when they are inoculated by the poison of a gall-insect.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: It must also be admitted that analogy fails to guide us towards any determination on several other points: for instance, whether cells, derived from the same parent-cell, may, in the regular course of growth, become developed into different structures, from absorbing peculiar kinds of nutriment, independently of their union with distinct gemmules.
next_sentence: With animals various polypoid excrescences and tumours are now generally admitted[910] to be the direct product, through proliferation, of normal cells which have become abnormal.

question: Man [MASK] tends to go to an extreme point in the selection, whether methodical or unconscious, of all useful and pleasing qualities.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Consequently highly-bred animals, when neglected, soon degenerate; but we have no reason to believe that the effects of long-continued selection would, if the conditions of life remained the same, be soon and completely lost.
next_sentence: This is an important principle, as it leads to continued divergence, and in some rare cases to convergence of character.

question: It [MASK] not under what climate, or for what purpose, they are kept, whether as food for man or beast, for draught or hunting, for clothing or mere pleasure ,--under all these circumstances domesticated animals and plants have varied to a much greater extent than the forms which in a state of nature are ranked as one species.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: With extremely few exceptions, all animals and plants which have been long domesticated, have varied greatly.
next_sentence: Why certain animals and plants have varied more under domestication than others we do not know, any more than why some are rendered more sterile than others under changed conditions of life.

question: As it is, seventy-three hands and seventy-five [MASK] were thus affected.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: I have tabulated the cases recorded in various     works or privately communicated {13} to me, of forty-six persons with     extra digits on one or both hands and feet; if in each case all four     extremities had been similarly affected, the table would have shown a     total of ninety-two hands and ninety-two feet each with six digits.
next_sentence: This proves, in contradiction to the result arrived at by Dr.     Struthers,[27] that the hands are not more frequently affected than the     feet.

question: The evil results from close [MASK] are difficult to detect, for they accumulate slowly, and differ much in degree with different species; whilst the good effects which almost invariably follow a cross are from the first manifest.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: But the former point is the more important of the two, inasmuch as the evidence is more decisive.
next_sentence: It should, however, be clearly understood that the advantage of close interbreeding, as far as the retention of character is concerned, is indisputable, and often outweighs the evil of a slight loss of constitutional vigour.

question: Some groups of animals are more affected than others, but with apparently [MASK] exceptions in every group.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: On the other hand, numerous facts have been given, showing that when animals are first subjected to captivity, even in their native land, and although allowed much liberty, their reproductive functions are often greatly impaired or quite annulled.
next_sentence: Some animals never or rarely couple: some couple freely, but never or rarely conceive.

question: Domestic races have often been intentionally modified by one or two crosses, made with some allied race, and occasionally even by repeated crosses with very distinct races; but in almost all such cases, long-continued and careful selection has been absolutely necessary, owing to the excessive variability of the [MASK] offspring, due to the principle of reversion.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Nevertheless, through unconscious selection, a whole body of individuals may be slowly modified, as we shall see in a future chapter, without separating them into distinct lots.
next_sentence: In a few instances, however, mongrels have retained a uniform character from their first production.

question: Here is a still more perplexing case: certain plants with variegated leaves, phloxes with striped flowers, [MASK] with seedless fruit, can all be securely propagated by the buds on cuttings; but the buds developed from the roots of these cuttings almost invariably lose their character and revert to their former condition.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: I can offer no satisfactory explanation of this fact.
next_sentence: Finally, we can see on the hypothesis of pangenesis that variability depends on at least two distinct groups of causes.

question: Modifications, in whatever manner caused, will be to a certain extent regulated by that co-ordinating power or nisus formativus, which is in fact a [MASK] of one of the forms of reproduction, displayed by many lowly organised beings in their power of fissiparous generation and budding.
source_info: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2) by Darwin, Charles Robert
title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: With plants the position of the flowers on the axis, and of the seeds in the capsule, sometimes leads, through a freer flow of sap, to changes of structure; but these changes are often due to reversion.
next_sentence: Finally, the effects of the laws, which directly or indirectly govern variability, may be largely influenced by man's selection, and will so far be determined by natural selection that changes advantageous to any race will be favoured and disadvantageous changes checked.

question: The white collar round the [MASK] of the mallard became much broader and more irregular, and white feathers appeared in the ducklings' wings . ''

title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: He found that he could not breed these wild ducks true for more than five or six generations, "as they then proved so much less beautiful.
next_sentence: They increased also in size of body; their legs became less fine, and they lost their elegant carriage.

next_sentence: Lastly, I assume that the gemmules in their dormant state have a mutual affinity for each other, leading to their aggregation either into buds or into the sexual elements.

question: The leg is the least profitable portion of the hog, and we therefore require no more of it than is absolutely [MASK] for the support of the rest . ''

title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)

next_sentence: Let any one compare the wild-boar with any improved breed, and he will see how effectually the legs have been shortened.

question: The experiment was repeated in the two following generations with plants raised from the self-fertilised and crossed plants, treated in exactly the same [MASK], and with nearly the same result.

title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)

next_sentence: In the second generation, the crossed     plants, which were again crossed, produced 121 seed-capsules, whilst     the self-fertilised plants, again self-fertilised, produced only 84     capsules.

question: It is perhaps a more probable view that plants which propagate themselves largely by one method, namely by buds, have not sufficient vital power or organised matter for the other method of sexual [MASK].

title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: Whether in these cases, as in those of double flowers and seedless     fruit, sexual sterility from changed conditions of life is the primary     cause which leads to the excessive development of the organs of     vegetation, is doubtful; though some evidence might be advanced in     favour of this view.
next_sentence: Several distinguished botanists and good practical judges believe that     long-continued propagation by cuttings, runners, tubers, bulbs, &c.,     independently of any excessive development of these parts, is the cause     of many plants failing to produce flowers and of others failing to     produce fertile flowers,--it is as if they had lost the habit of sexual     generation.

question: Many variations, however, are from the first connected by the [MASK] of correlation.

title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: As every detail of structure in each species is closely adapted to its general {415} habits of life, it will rarely happen that one part alone will be modified; but the co-adapted modifications, as formerly shown, need not be absolutely simultaneous.
next_sentence: Hence it follows that even closely-allied species rarely or never differ from each other by some one character alone; and this same remark applies to a certain extent to domestic races; for these, if they differ much, generally differ in many respects.

question: This latter power seems to us, in our [MASK], to act in most cases quite capriciously.

title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: In conclusion, some of the cases above given,--for instance, that of the trumpeter pigeon,--prove that there is a wide difference between mere inheritance and prepotency.
next_sentence: The very same character, even though it be an abnormal or monstrous one, such as silky feathers, may be transmitted by different species, when crossed, either with prepotent force or singular feebleness.

question: It is almost necessary that a large number of individuals should be reared; for thus there will be a fair chance of variations of the [MASK] nature arising, and every individual with the slightest blemish or in any degree inferior may be freely rejected.

title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: That methodical selection may be successful, the closest attention and discernment, combined with unwearied patience, are absolutely necessary; and these same qualities, though not indispensable, are highly serviceable in the case of unconscious selection.
next_sentence: Hence length of time is an important element of success.

title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)

question: But no one is thus led to doubt that it is a general law of nature that phanerogamic plants should produce flowers, and that these flowers should produce [MASK].

next_sentence: When they fail, we believe that such plants would perform their proper functions under different conditions, or that they formerly did so and will do so again.

title: The Variation of Animals and Plants Under Domestication, Volume II (of 2)
prev_sentence: In some cases we find correlation without being able even to conjecture what is the nature of the connexion, as with various correlated monstrosities and diseases.
next_sentence: Numerous curious instances have been given of peculiarities of constitution, in correlation with colour, as shown by the immunity of individuals of some one colour from certain diseases, from the attacks of parasites, and from the action of certain vegetable poisons.

question: They are noticed here because they illustrate analogous differences in closely allied natural species, and because such changed habits of life, whether due to use and disuse, or to the direct [MASK] of external conditions, or to so-called spontaneous variation, would be apt to lead to modifications of structure.
